       <dc:creator>Anne C Osterman</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.215">        <title>Digital preservation of scholarly content, focusing on the example of the CLOCKSS Archive</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.215</link>            <description><p>In this article the author explores the development of digital preservation, including consideration of what it is and what it is not, and looks at the challenges that preservation of multiple formats of digital scholarship brings. After setting definitions and considering the different types of archive currently available, the mission and principles of the CLOCKSS Archive are explained. The wrap-up covers the changing nature of scholarly communication, a few of the challenges and the approach to these taken by the CLOCKSS Archive.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Randy S Kiefer</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.186">        <title>The NISO Open Discovery Initiative: promoting transparency in discovery</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.186</link>            <description><p>In June 2014, the NISO Open Discovery Initiative (ODI) working group published its best practice recommendations for indexed-based discovery services. Addressing the need for a unified search, these services use an aggregated meta-index and enable users to query a wide range of resources \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd both licensed and free \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd from multiple providers. Discovery services have largely supplanted the previous generation of metasearch systems and offer superior performance, much wider search scope and no limit on the number of results retrieved by the system. Although these relatively new discovery services have been widely adopted by libraries on a global basis, the ODI recommendations should assist with the further development of this industry. This article provides some background for the ODI, a summary of the published recommendations, and a call to action.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Jenny Walker</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.222">        <title>Could we ever get rid of usage statistics?</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.222</link>            <description><p>UKSG is pleased to be able to publish the winning entry in the Usus Travel Award competition, sponsored by COUNTER. The award is made to a librarian who contributes the best opinion piece, and it can be used towards travel to the Charleston Conference, UKSG Conference, Electronic Resources &amp; Libraries Conference or NASIG Conference. The winning entries were judged by the Usus supervisory board, and the Co-Editors of <em>Insights</em> would like to add their congratulations to the 2015 winner, Nancy Bennett, whose essay is reproduced below.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Nancy Bennett</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.158">        <title>Untying knots and joining dots: the role of librarians in the scholarly communication environment</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.158</link>            <description><p>This opinion piece on the role of libraries in the scholarly communication environment covers the following issues: the notion of librarians as the proxies and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdmiddleware\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of the scholarly communications landscape; the need for librarians to be willing to adapt their practices in order to ease some of the complexities inherent in research communications; a plea for publishers to provide simpler, more straightforward and transparent subscription and open access (OA) offers to libraries; and some thoughts on where rapid developments in digital technologies might lead the information professions.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Martin Wolf</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.166">        <title>Co-operating for gold open access without APCs</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.166</link>            <description><p>While article processing charges (APCs) are emerging as a key way in which existing publishers can adapt to gold open access (OA), this mode is problematic in many ways. Considering the existing subscription publication ecosystem as a risk/cost-pooling mechanism leads to the conclusion that APCs are a concentration of risk that may come with damaging institutional consequences, particularly in the humanities disciplines. Consortial and co-operative modes of funding gold OA, however, do not come with these drawbacks but are susceptible to \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfree riders\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. In this article, the theoretical backdrop to these models is addressed and the range of current offerings evaluated. Noting that classical economic incentives do not seem to operate in a world of inter-library loans, the article ends with a description of the model that is being implemented for the <em>Open Library of Humanities</em> initiative, funded by the Andrew W Mellon Foundation.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Martin Paul Eve</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.176">        <title>Information without frontiers \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd barriers and solutions</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.176</link>            <description><p>Following the success of the first UKSG Forum, it was decided to hold a second \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd this time in a larger, central venue: the Grand Connaught Rooms in London. Under the umbrella title, also the title of this collection of three summaries of lightning talks from the event, were grouped a number of useful topics: Expanding Library Boundaries, The Human Touch, The Future of Library Discovery (a debate), Library Systems, Academic Content Beyond the Academy, UKSG Research and Innovation, Publishing Innovation, Open Access Monographs, KB+, Altmetrics, User Experience and Data Enrichment.</p><p>In this article we bring you summaries of the talks by Anna Grigson, Catherine McManamon and Sam Herbert.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Anna Grigson</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Catherine McManamon</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Herbert</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.214">        <title>Scholarly publishing for the network generation</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.214</link>            <description><p>The increasing momentum towards opening up various dimensions of society is discussed in this article, and the authors consider whether \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdopen\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is now an unstoppable force for change in the world. Various topics within research communication, such as open access (OA) and post-publication peer review (PPPR), are considered from the perspective of the authors as participants in the scholarly communication community of more than 20 years\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd standing, with both for- and non-profit credentials.</p><p>The authors explore how harnessing the wisdom of the crowd in rating everyday services manifests itself by improving our ability to make choices in our daily lives. They explain how this network effect can be applied to scholarly communication and how it provided some of the inspiration behind the launch of ScienceOpen, the research and OA publishing network, in May 2014. This publishing platform is then described as an example of democratizing publishing. The increasing importance of software development in publishing and the need for stand-alone expertise in this space (as opposed to a publisher-centric approach) is also discussed.</p><p>Finally, the authors consider the role that the impact factor and the promotion/tenure system play in holding back progress in scholarly communication and they highlight the efforts of early career researchers to break the stalemate by taking \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdopen\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd pledges.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Liz Allen</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Stephanie Dawson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.218">        <title>Europeana Newspapers: searching digitized historical newspapers from 23 European countries</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.218</link>            <description><p>Europeana Newspapers is a European Commission-funded project which is refining, aggregating and giving researchers online access to historical newspaper content from 23 European libraries. It also offers free, open source tools which individual libraries can use to assess refinement quality and metadata standards in relation to their own digital newspaper collections. The content made available by the project is available both through Europeana and a dedicated newspaper browser. Europeana is a way to see the newspapers in the context of over 30 million other items of cultural heritage, while the dedicated browser hosted on The European Library site gives researchers the possibility to refine their search terms (e.g. by date, publishing country, issue) and to search the full text of many newspapers. So far, the browser, which has been online for approximately one year, has proven popular with researchers, and further improvements to its functionality are planned in 2015. This could include the ability for users to tag articles or to edit, and help correct, the full text of individual articles.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Marieke Willems</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Rossitza Atanassova</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.217">        <title>The Global Open Knowledgebase (GOKb): open linked data supporting electronic resources management and scholarly communication</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.217</link>            <description><p>The Global Open Knowledgebase (GOKb), a partnership between Kuali OLE and Jisc, is an open data repository of information related to e-resources as they are acquired and managed by libraries. Because GOKb tracks change over time \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd titles, publishers, packages \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and can be used to populate other tools with data, it is changing the way that libraries think about the knowledge base. Propagation of authoritative and enhanced data about e-resources has the potential to benefit all actors in the supply chain from publishers to libraries. GOKb can also serve as a platform to explore how open knowledge base data can contribute to the broader scholarly community infrastructure, particularly around open access (OA).</p></description>            <dc:creator>Kristin Antelman</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Kristen Wilson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.179">        <title>Academic publishing in Portugal: threats and major opportunities</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.179</link>            <description><p>This article begins with an analysis of the current state of scientific publication in Portugal, with reference to the impact of the open access (OA) policies of commercial and academic publishers. It then explores the relationship between academic publishing and institutional repositories, discussing the way they should complement one another, taking as reference the activities of the Portuguese Association of Higher Education Publishers (APEES). Final remarks deal more specifically with the UC Digitalis project from Coimbra University Press (CUP), and the way it is committed to the goal of fostering science produced in Portuguese-speaking countries.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Delfim Le\ufffd\ufffdo</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.168">        <title>Developing strategies to ensure compliance with funders\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd open access policies</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.168</link>            <description><p>Funding bodies for higher education institutions (HEIs) in the United Kingdom (UK) have recently introduced policies with a strong focus on open access (OA). The Research Councils UK (RCUK) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPolicy on Open Access\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd mandates OA compliance through either hybrid or pure OA journals, or through self-archiving. The Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE) has recently introduced a self-archiving policy for journal articles and conference proceedings. Both policies have necessitated new practices among UK HEIs that relate to advocacy, adoption of internal OA policies, managing article processing charges (APCs), and monitoring and reporting compliance with them. This case study details the path Royal Holloway University of London, has taken to navigate its way through these recent changes and challenges.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Nancy Pontika</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Dace Rozenberga</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.173">        <title>The customer is always right? Assessing the value of patron-driven acquisition at the University of Huddersfield</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/uksg.173</link>            <description><p>A small-scale patron-driven acquisition (PDA) study at the University of Huddersfield is discussed in this article. The authors briefly describe the background to PDA at Huddersfield before discussing data from the 2014 PDA pilot with the e-book supplier Ebook Library (EBL). The pilot produced two sets of data, usage reports using COUNTER statistics and a short questionnaire designed by the Library. These results led to a major alteration to the collection management and development policy, where PDA is now embedded into the Library book fund.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Graham Stone</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Briony Heyhoe-Pullar</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2015-03-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2015-03-05</prism:publicationDate> librarian</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.199</link>                <dc:creator>Dr Diana Leitch</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date> rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.185">        <title>Profile - Danny Kingsley</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.185</link>                    <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.155">        <title>Implementing e-resource access for alumni at King's College London: a case study</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.155</link>            <description> <p>University libraries are increasingly considering ways to develop the library services offered to their alumni in response to growing demand. In particular, there has been a rising interest in how university libraries can extend access to e-resources to include provision of access for alumni, raising a number of challenging questions around the licensing of e-resources for alumni as well as access and funding considerations. This article describes the work carried out at King's College London to investigate extending e-resource access to alumni and the experience of implementing access to JSTOR in 2012. The article then examines some of the barriers that King's have faced in building on this work.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Anna Fran\ufffd\ufffda</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.166">        <title>Augmenting discovery data and analytics to enhance library services</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.166</link>            <description> <p>Discovery services have become a norm in academic libraries. Usage data from these services has historically emphasized quantitative data such as full-text downloads, numbers of searches performed and title usage. Okanagan College Library incorporated Google Analytics into their discovery service in order to go beyond vendor-supplied quantitative data and obtain valuable qualitative information about users. This information can now be used to shape library services such as collection development, public services and interface design. The user-behaviour data findings are presented, along with suggestions for using this information to enhance library services.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Ro\ufffd\ufffdn Janyk</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.183">        <title>Editorial</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.183</link>                <dc:creator>Lorraine Estelle</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Steve Sharp</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.200">        <title>A day in the life of <i>a programme manager, publishing support</i> </title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.200</link>                <dc:creator>Julie Walker</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.184">        <title>People in the News - Susanna Lob</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.184</link>                    <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.186">        <title>People</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.186</link>                <dc:creator>John Jardine</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.157">        <title>ISTEX: a powerful project for scientific and technical electronic resources archives</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.157</link>            <description> <p>To strengthen and facilitate French research: this is the goal the Ministry of Higher Education and Research wants to achieve with its ISTEX project. France, along with the rest of the world, has faced huge price increases in the acquisition of academic electronic resources during the last decade, and its institutions are now finding it difficult to pay to access them. The Ministry has therefore decided to invest in an extensive electronic archives acquisition programme in order to give the academic and research community nationwide access to a very large corpus of data in all disciplines. This project will consist of two phases: acquisition of the archives themselves and the development of a single platform to host the data. This platform will offer seamless unique access to all the resources purchased and will provide a range of efficient services to researchers.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Andr\ufffd\ufffd Dazy</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.172">        <title>The open library and its enemies</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.172</link>            <description><p>In the age of electronics an open society \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd one in which questions can be asked, where critical thinking is not just permitted but encouraged and where investigation rather than ideology is used to seek out the truth about the world (the open society according to Karl Popper) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd has also to be an open data society because reusable, structured data has become the main machine for doing the heavy lifting of moving knowledge around, just as books move ideas around.</p><p>An open library is one that embodies the Open Definition in its working practices, one that is available and accessible, open to all participants, and which offers services that can be freely shared. Such institutions are pillars of any open data society.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Bill Thompson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.171">        <title>The future of scholarly communications</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.171</link>            <description>The academic publishing industry is set to celebrate 350 years of peer-reviewed scientific journals. However, there are significant shifts in the practice of scholarship, as scholars and citizens alike participate in an increasingly digital world. Is the scholarly article still fit for its purpose in this data-driven world, with new interdisciplinary methodologies and increasing automation? How might it be enhanced or replaced with new kinds of digital research objects, so as not to restrict innovation but rather create a flourishing sense-making network of humans and machines? The emerging paradigm of social machines provides a lens onto future developments in scholarship and scholarly collaboration, as we live and study in a hybrid physical-digital sociotechnical system of enormous and growing scale.</description>            <dc:creator>David De Roure</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.170">        <title>Open scholarship and research management</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.170</link>            <description>Open scholarship is one of the most profound influences on the research landscape. It is shaping institutional policy and strategy, changing scholarly behaviour, and raising substantial questions about infrastructure and investment. Whilst undoubtedly challenging, adapting to an open scholarship environment presents enormous opportunities for research organizations and the research management and knowledge and communications professions. This article sets out some of these issues from the perspective of a university research manager.</description>            <dc:creator>John Rogers</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.174">        <title>Thinking the unthinkable \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd doing away with the library catalogue</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.174</link>            <description><p>At Utrecht University we strongly believe that academic libraries have lost their role in the discovery of scientific information and should focus on delivery instead.</p><p>Without your own discovery tool you might feel stark naked. However, we have to admit that others can do a better job on discovery, so don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt spend too much time on this. Make a priority of your delivery task and rethink the way you can provide value for your users.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Simone Kortekaas</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Bianca Kramer</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.153">        <title>The effect of discovery systems on online journal usage: a longitudinal study</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.153</link>            <description>Many academic libraries are implementing discovery services as a way of giving their users a single comprehensive search option for all library resources. These tools are designed to change the research experience, yet very few studies have investigated the impact of discovery service implementation. This study examines one aspect of that impact by asking whether usage of publisher-hosted journal content changes after implementation of a discovery tool. Libraries that have begun using the four major discovery services have seen an increase in usage of this content, suggesting that for this particular type of material, discovery services have a positive impact on use. Though all discovery services significantly increased usage relative to a no discovery service control group, some had a greater impact than others, and there was extensive variation in usage change among libraries using the same service. Future phases of this study will look at other types of content.</description>            <dc:creator>Michael Levine-Clark</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>John Mcdonald</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jason S Price</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.178">        <title>Managing open access (OA) workflows at the University of St Andrews: challenges and Pathfinder solutions</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.178</link>            <description>This article arose out of a presentation given to the UKSG seminar on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdManaging Open Access: pain points and workflows\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. It presents a case study on the workflows in place at the University of St Andrews and how these are developing to meet funder compliance policies and the challenge of the new HEFCE Research Excellence Framework (REF) open access (OA) policy. The case study describes the research environment at St Andrews and in particular the challenges faced and how these may be answered. Since the seminar in May 2014, the Open Access Research Publications Support Team has engaged in a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLean\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd exercise to evaluate and streamline workflows within the institution. St Andrews is also now a partner in the LOCH project, one of the Jisc Pathfinder projects. The paper gives an update on recent activities and looks at strategies and practical ideas for improving workflows and removing pain points.</description>            <dc:creator>Janet Aucock</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.175">        <title>Managing open access: the first year of managing RCUK and Wellcome Trust OA funding at the University of Glasgow Library</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.175</link>            <description>Many institutions have been awarded funds by the Research Councils UK (RCUK), in the form of a block grant, to cover the costs of article processing charges (APCs) for open access (OA). This article discusses how this grant (and also the open access fund awarded by the Wellcome Trust) is being managed at the University of Glasgow. It looks at the overall policy for managing these funds at the University and at the systems and processes set in place by the University Library to deal with this new area of activity. There are significant challenges for institutions in managing individual APCs and the article discusses some of these challenges. The new Research Excellence Framework (REF) policy on open access was introduced in March 2014 and will have implications for the management of open access by institutions. Finally, the paper looks at where next for OA management at the University.</description>            <dc:creator>Susan Ashworth</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Valerie Mccutcheon</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Laura Roy</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.177">        <title>Diversity, collaboration and renewal: reflections on the 2014 UKSG conference</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.177</link>            <description> <p>Summing up his experience of the three packed days of the 2014 UKSG conference in Harrogate, Gareth Johnson said that he had three key take-away words: diversity, collaboration and renewal. This short article, based on the report he wrote after attending the conference as a sponsored student, explains these lasting impressions and also highlights the way UKSG itself has continued to expand, bringing together the disparate stakeholders and engendering a real dynamic and at times electrifying atmosphere of cross-fertilization and possibility.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Gareth J Johnson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.158">        <title>What's the use?: analysing student citations to provide new insights into e-book usage</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.158</link>            <description> <p>This article reports on a small-scale user-focused piece of research carried out at the University of Sussex. In an attempt to better understand the impact of e-books on student outputs, citation analysis was performed on coursework to identify the e-books that had been used. Of the students surveyed, 11.6% cited an e-book in their work and, for this particular group, EBL was found to be the most popular collection. However, cross reference with the Library discovery tool and Google revealed that e-books available from the web were cited more than those from library collections. Interviews uncovered a spectrum of usage, leading to the conclusion that a comprehensive e-book strategy is required that makes students aware of their benefits, equips them with the skills needed for effective use and increases the number of e-books available.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Antony Groves</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.131">        <title>The university as publisher revisited</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.131</link>            <description> <p>This article explores the growing involvement of libraries in providing publishing services for the informal scholarly outputs traditionally referred to as \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgray literature\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. By envisioning institutional repository (IR) infrastructure as a publishing platform, libraries can bring conference proceedings, technical reports, niche journals, white papers and other hard-to-source materials into the mainstream. The opportunities of such an approach for scholars, libraries and university presses open to collaboration are considered. Several directions for future expansion of this activity, such as the publication of student scholarship and the development of more formal products linked to gray literature, are suggested.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Charles Watkinson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.180">        <title>People</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.180</link>                <dc:creator>John Jardine</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.179">        <title>Editorial</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.179</link>                <dc:creator>Lorraine Estelle</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Steve Sharp</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.176">        <title>People in the News - Emily Gore</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.176</link>                    <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.168">        <title>A day in the life of <i>a Co-ordinator, Scholarly Communications</i> </title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.168</link>                <dc:creator>Amy Buckland</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.162">        <title>Is rational discussion of open access possible?</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.162</link>            <description> <p>Open Access (OA), like any other model or strategy for the dissemination of knowledge, carries with it clear benefits as well as costs and downsides. These vary depending on the OA strategy in question, and in order for OA to bring maximum benefit to the world of scholarship, its costs and benefits need be examined carefully and dispassionately so that the former can be maximized and the latter minimized. Unfortunately, the OA advocacy community tends to resist all attempts to examine OA in this way, to the point that those who approach OA in a spirit of critical analysis (rather than celebration and evangelism) are attacked and punished. This article describes the problem, provides examples of it, and proposes strategies for promoting a more rigorous and analytical discussion of OA.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Rick Anderson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.97">        <title>Digitization: a successful collaborative partnership between library and publisher</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.97</link>            <description> <p>While archives across the UK are recognizing the potential of digitization to unlock their treasures, the realities of a large-scale digitization project can be daunting for any institution. This article will explore how partnerships between publishers and archives can help the latter face the challenges of getting content digitized. It will take a look behind the scenes of the longstanding partnership between Adam Matthew (AM; a specialist publisher of digital primary source collections), and The National Archives at Kew (TNA; the UK government's official archive). It will explore how this kind of relationship develops; how the production process works, and how products are brought through to market.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Martha Fogg</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.160">        <title>Walls of straw \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the cyber risks to higher education</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.160</link>            <description> <p>Globally, in every facet of life, advances in communications technology and our reliance on computers and the internet allow us to live and work more efficiently than ever before. Higher education relies on the development of knowledge and the need to conduct and communicate research activity. Universities are often bound in research activity to business, government and other organizations whose interests need to be protected and managed. But is there a disparity in approach? Is research activity, security and the protection of privileged, proprietary and classified information appropriately implemented and managed in higher education? In this article the author questions: are there gaps open to cyberattack?</p></description>            <dc:creator>Phillip Wood</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.148">        <title>The open data imperative</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.148</link>            <description> <p>The information revolution of recent decades is a world historical event that is changing the lives of individuals, societies and economies and with major implications for science, research and learning. It offers profound opportunities to explore phenomena that were hitherto beyond our power to resolve, and at the same time is undermining the process whereby concurrent publication of scientific concept and evidence (data) permitted scrutiny, replication and refutation and that has been the bedrock of scientific progress and of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdself-correction\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd since the inception of the first scientific journals in the 17th century. Open publication, release and sharing of data are vital habits that need to be redefined and redeveloped for the modern age by the research community if it is to exploit technological opportunities, maintain self-correction and maximize the contribution of research to human understanding and welfare.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Professor Geoffrey Boulton</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.116">        <title>MOOCs at Karolinska Institutet University Library</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.116</link>            <description> <p>This article discusses how recent developments around net-based learning, with massive open online courses (MOOCs) as an example, can provide an opportunity for university libraries to redefine their role within the university organization. At the Karolinska Institutet University Library (KIB), we are deeply involved in the process of producing our University's first MOOCs. This has given the Library many new opportunities, but we have also come across some challenges that we have needed to address. A new role implies many new considerations, and gives the Library the opportunity to develop the way it works and the services it provides. Libraries such as ours have excellent opportunities to really contribute to the development of our universities by offering our expertise in the fields of literature acquisition including open access (OA), metadata and archiving, information literacy and student support, ICT and pedagogy. This is more relevant than ever in the age of MOOCs.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Carina Ahlberg</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.159">        <title>Profile - Sven Fund</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.159</link>                    <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.89">        <title>Open access: a perspective from the humanities</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.89</link>            <description> <p>This article surveys the debates over UK public policy for open access (OA) since 2012 from the perspective of scholars in the humanities. It isolates points in Research Council and REF policy that have come under criticism from the humanities community for their basis in science practice, and assesses the progress that has been made in addressing these concerns. Issues considered include \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgold\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgreen\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd models of OA, the role of university managers in determining where and what academics can publish, embargo periods and licensing. The author is President of the Royal Historical Society.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Peter Mandler</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.167">        <title>Key Issue - Out of the shadows: the case for a national repository of open content</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.167</link>                <dc:creator>John MacColl</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.161">        <title>The diaries of the sponsored students and early career professionals</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.161</link>                    <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.151">        <title>Channelling information flows: a young researcher\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds approach to knowledge management</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.151</link>            <description>As the volume of scientific literature continues to grow at an impressive pace, so too does the diversity of tools and approaches that are being proposed to track this knowledge. In the midst of such a vast ecosystem of journals and software, identifying meaningful innovation, as well as continuing to innovate, is essential to the emergence of powerful, flexible and easy-to-use \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdchannels\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd which researchers need to navigate the current scientific literature. In this article, the author uses the example of his own information consumption habits to suggest what he sees as the key components of such channels.</description>            <dc:creator>Guilhem Chalancon</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.149">        <title>Developing a shared analytics service for academic libraries</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.149</link>            <description><p>Universities and colleges have a rich seam of data, created as students, researchers and staff interact with the systems and services across their campuses. The potential for this data to transform the student and researcher experience, and improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the institution, is currently locked away in the diverse and complex data sets and systems employed by each institution. Even where these data sets are available, making sense of them can be difficult and resource intensive.</p><p>This article describes the efforts of the Library Analytics and Metrics Project (LAMP) to develop a shared, national service to enable institutions and libraries to make sense of their disparate and diverse data sets and enable them to spend their precious time and resources acting upon it to improve the student and researcher experience.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Ben Showers</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.152">        <title>The research cycle and research data management (RDM): innovating approaches at the University of Westminster</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.152</link>            <description>This article presents a case study based on experience of delivering a more joined-up approach to supporting institutional research activity and processes, research data management (RDM) and open access (OA). The result of this small study, undertaken at the University of Westminster in 2013, indicates that a more holistic approach should be adopted, embedding RDM more fully into the wider research management landscape and taking researchers\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd priorities into consideration. Rapid development of an innovative pilot system followed closely on from a positive engagement with researchers, and today a purpose-built, integrated and fully working set of tools are functioning within the virtual research environment (VRE). This provides a coherent \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthread\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd to support researchers, doctoral students and professional support staff throughout the research cycle. The article describes the work entailed in more detail, together with the impact achieved so far and what future work is planned.</description>            <dc:creator>Ken Chad</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Suzanne Enright</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.154">        <title>Participants\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd perceptions of a MOOC</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.154</link>            <description>There is currently limited information available on participants\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd perceptions of massive open online courses (MOOCs). This article presents the findings of a study at the University of Edinburgh examining the perceptions of a group of participants registered on a MOOC in equine nutrition, which ran for a period of five weeks and attracted 24,000 students to register. A self-completion survey was designed with a series of Likert scale questions, organized to gather students\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd perceptions of participating in the MOOC. Participants on this course rated the learning materials and overall MOOC experience very highly; however, further work is required to elucidate why a much lower percentage of participants held the interactions in less regard.</description>            <dc:creator>Jo-Anne Murray</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-07-07</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-07-07</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.112">        <title>Editorial</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.112</link>                <dc:creator>Ellen Collins</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Caren Milloy</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.121">        <title>Open access monographs: a humanities research perspective</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.121</link>            <description> <p>This article discusses the thoughts of a humanities researcher in relation to open access (OA) publishing. Digital media have dramatically improved access to historic texts but library e-books are frustrating due to software and loan arrangements. Authors of illustrated books risk losing control of book design, although new media offer opportunities to improve image quality and access. Alfred Tennyson's career shows that authors have been sensitive about the physical form of their work since the Victorian period and ignoring the material significance of the book could make us overlook the fundamental changes that the e-book represents. Monographs retain value as a way of evaluating substantive research projects and those published through the OA process will have great advantages over the commercial e-book. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdGreen\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd OA publishing is impractical for humanities scholars and funded \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgold\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd OA publishing is likely to involve a labour-intensive application process.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Dr Jim Cheshire</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.163">        <title>Open access monographs and the role of the library</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.163</link>            <description> <p>If open access (OA) books are to succeed, they need to operate in a way that works for academic libraries. Humanities researchers rely upon libraries to help them find and access many of the books they need for their research. Furthermore, many business models require direct input from librarians in the form of funding for first-copy costs or alternative formats. This article uses interviews with librarians and repository managers at four UK universities to consider some key issues for OA monographs from the point of view of librarians, and concludes with a reflection on these findings from the point of view of the University of Huddersfield's Library.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Ellen Collins</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Graham Stone</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.120">        <title>Building it together: collaboration in university-based open access book publishing</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.120</link>            <description> <p>Open access (OA) book publishing in the humanities and social sciences is becoming technically more feasible and financially more desirable. After securing funding for the development of a business model based on a pilot book series, the University of Heidelberg is joining this development and building an infrastructure to publish OA books on campus. The challenges facing such new publishing outlets are considerable. This article argues that the best strategy to build the prestige, affordability and competitiveness necessary to succeed is collaboration. Accomplishing this within the OA community will prove less difficult than extending collaboration beyond it because many agencies and individuals still lack information about, and are often unconvinced of, the merits of open access. The key lies in offering excellence in manuscript development to revitalize the most important collaboration of all: that between publisher and author.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Dr Andrea Hacker</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.164">        <title>How should we fund open access monographs and what do you think is the most likely way that funding will happen?</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.164</link>            <description><p>The contributors to the <em>Insights OA monograph supplement</em> were invited to respond to this question, and their thought-provoking and sometimes conflicting replies below make interesting reading.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Michael C R Davies</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Paul Ayris</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Graham Stone</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jim Cheshire</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Rhodri Jackson</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Andrea Hacker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Mercedes Bunz</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Eelco Ferwerda</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hazel Newton</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Marin Dacos</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Pierre Mounier</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Yrsa Neuman</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.46">        <title>Open access monograph business models</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.46</link>            <description><p>In recent years, a number of business models have been developed for open access (OA) monographs in the humanities and social sciences (HSS). While each model has been created in response to specific circumstances and needs, some commonalities can be observed. This article outlines some of the main types of model to support the costs of publishing OA books and provides examples of these models across the world.</p><p>It is followed by three short sketches providing more depth on: firstly, a traditional publisher's OA monograph offer; secondly, a licensing-based model which draws from existing library budgets; and finally, an experiment with delayed open access for books in philosophy: <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1629/2048-7754.118" target="_blank">http://dx.doi.org/10.1629/2048-7754.118</a></p></description>            <dc:creator>Eelco Ferwerda</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.141">        <title>Calibrating the parameters: changing hearts and minds about open access monographs</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.141</link>            <description> <p>The advent of open access (OA) publishing presents welcome new opportunities for reducing the barriers of cost and time to the dissemination of research work in UK universities. However, it does present some challenges to the traditional model of monograph publication in the humanities and social sciences. In common with many other academic institutions, the University of Sussex is developing policies that will permit it to embrace OA publication. This paper describes how, in doing this, Sussex is addressing the challenges associated with OA to ensure that the careers of doctoral students, academics and researchers are not affected adversely by the change in the publishing landscape for monographs both in the UK and internationally.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Professor Michael C R Davies</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.118">        <title>Snapshots of three open access business models</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.118</link>            <description><p>Following on from Eelco Ferwerda's introduction to different OA monograph business models ( <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1629/2048-7754.46" target="_blank">http://dx.doi.org/10.1629/2048-7754.46</a>), Hazel Newton (Palgrave Macmillan), Marin Dacos and Pierre Mounier (OpenEdition Books) and Yrsa Neuman (\ufffd\ufffdbo Akademi University) explain the different OA business models that they are currently working with.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Hazel Newton</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Marin Dacos</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Pierre Mounier</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Yrsa Neuman</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.117">        <title>The publisher journey for OUP</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.117</link>            <description> <p>The journey towards open access (OA) monograph publishing is incomplete. Since the publication of the Finch Report and in an environment of improving funding for OA monographs, publishers have made tentative moves into the OA monograph space, but there are a number of questions to be answered before one or more truly successful and sustainable business models can be identified. Oxford University Press (OUP) is a large monograph publisher, and has been publishing OA journals for a decade. It is only in the last year though that OUP has made significant moves towards OA monograph publishing, participating in the OAPEN-UK project and considering other options. The challenge for OUP and the publishing industry is to work with authors, funders and other interested parties to develop OA monograph publishing options which work for all involved and safeguard the future of a crucial element of the scholarly publishing landscape.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Rhodri Jackson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.122">        <title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Returned\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: on the future of monographic books</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.122</link>            <description> <p>This article evaluates the current state of academic book publishing based on the findings of the Hybrid Publishing Lab's business model research. With students relying more and more on Google and Wikipedia, the role of books within today's university studies is a difficult one. From the perspective of publishers, open access (OA) embracing the digital is seen as one potential way to bridge this gap between online search engines and traditional monographs. To illustrate this further, the article delivers an overview of its findings, which highlight changes in academic publishing: publishers have switched their emphasis from delivering a product to creating a service, whereby the author rather than the reader becomes their most focused-on customer. Research frameworks, funding and conventions about academic careers, however, often still need to adjust to this new development. If these frameworks acknowledge and foster OA publishing, and new experiments with collaborative book productions flourish, the monograph will have a future.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Mercedes Bunz</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.140">        <title>Open access e-books: the role of the institution</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.140</link>            <description> <p>This article explains the policy position taken by University College London (UCL) in establishing the UCL Press. It sets the creation of the Press against the background of national open access (OA) policy development in the UK. UCL Press, repatriated from a commercial provider, was relaunched as an OA press as part of UCL Library Services on 1 August 2013. The Press will publish both OA electronic journals and OA monographs, with a particular emphasis in the latter on the arts, humanities and social sciences. UCL is largely funding Press activity from its own internal funds, seeing OA as an opportunity rather than a threat.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Paul Ayris</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-04-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-04-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.115">        <title>Open access for REF2020</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.115</link>            <description> <p>Open access (OA) may have been the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbig thing\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in 2013 but the OA juggernaut is still rolling and plans are now afoot for the requirements for the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnext REF\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (which from now on we will refer to as REF2020). In 2013, on behalf of the four UK Funding Councils, the Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE) undertook a two-stage consultation exercise on open access requirements for articles submitted to REF2020. There are a number of nuances and caveats to the current proposals. This article will reflect on what the probable rules might be, and their implications for research managers, administrators and institutional repository managers alike.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Simon Kerridge</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Phil Ward</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.130">        <title>PeerJ \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd more than just a publisher</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.130</link>            <description><p>PeerJ Inc (the open access publisher of both <em>PeerJ</em> and <em>PeerJ PrePrints</em>) announced itself in mid-2012, and started publishing articles in February 2013. Although to the casual observer, PeerJ might be thought of as \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdjust another open access (OA) publisher\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, in fact (as evidenced by several industry awards) it is building an environment which has publishing at its core, but which also addresses the needs of the academic community in several additional ways. In this article, one of the co-founders of PeerJ describes innovations such as their \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdindividual-centric\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd business model; their \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdoptional open peer-review\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd system; the PeerJ contribution points; the visual design; and several important aspects of their philosophy which together are creating a publishing system suitable for the needs of the 21st-century academic.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Peter Binfield</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.113">        <title>SEEK!: creating and crowdfunding a game-based open educational resource to improve information literacy</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.113</link>            <description> <p>Crowdfunding was used for the development and production of an information literacy game, SEEK!, in 2012. The game aims to build skills around creating a search strategy and is deliberately generic and adaptable. This article outlines the reasons for using such a game for the teaching of information skills, the process of gaining funding via the crowdfunding platform Indiegogo and some future developments that build on the initial game creation and use.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Andrew Walsh</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.144">        <title>People in the News - Bryn Geffert</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.144</link>                    <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.146">        <title>Editorial</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.146</link>                <dc:creator>Steve Sharp</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lorraine Estelle</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.111">        <title>Development of open access in China: strategies, practices, challenges</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.111</link>            <description> <p>China's rapid growth in scientific R&D in recent years provides solid evidence for the country's innovation-driven development strategy, but also puts increasing demand on open access (OA) to publicly funded research results. This article looks at ways in which the Chinese government, funders, research and library communities are all rising to this challenge, and at future challenges still to be met. As a major scientific publishing country with its estimated 5,000 STM journals, China's place in the international OA publishing scene is considered in detail, with the author concluding that he believes open access to publicly funded research in China will soon become the accepted norm, as all levels of scientific policymakers fulfil their political, professional and international responsibilities, to the benefit of Chinese research and society.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Dr Xiaolin Zhang</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.114">        <title>Seeking a fresh perspective: a research funder's view of open access</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.114</link>            <description> <p>For open access (OA) to become a reality, all stakeholders will need to engage positively with each other to rise to the substantial practical challenges it brings. This means moving beyond advocacy and resistance towards a more mature, evidence-based dialogue that seeks to understand all perspectives and find workable solutions. For research funders, scholarly publication delivers crucial public benefits; funders' OA mandates should be seen as tools for maximizing these benefits. The Higher Education Funding Council for England's (HEFCE) policy for open access in the next Research Excellence Framework (REF) has been put together by listening to all sides of the debate, and its success depends on continuing positive, sensitive and engaged discussions between everyone involved.</p></description>            <dc:creator>David Sweeney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Ben Johnson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.129">        <title>CHORUS \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd providing a scalable solution for public access to scholarly research</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.129</link>            <description><p>CHORUS (Clearinghouse for the Open Research of the United States) offers an open technology platform in response to the public access requirements of US federal funding agencies, researchers, institutions and the public. It is focused on five principal sets of functions: <em>identification</em>, <em>preservation</em>, <em>discovery</em>, <em>access</em>, and <em>compliance</em> . CHORUS facilitates public access to peer-reviewed publications, after a determined embargo period (where applicable), for each discipline and agency. By leveraging existing tools such as CrossRef, FundRef and ORCID, CHORUS allows a greater proportion of funding to remain focused on research. CHORUS identifies articles that report on federally funded research and enables a reader to access the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbest available version\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd free of charge, via the publisher. It is a scalable solution that offers maximum efficiency for all parties by automating as much of the process as is possible. CHORUS launched in pilot phase in September 2013, and the production phase will begin in early 2014.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Howard Ratner</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>H Frederick Dylla</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>David Crotty</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.132">        <title>Who are the winners? E-book consortial purchasing</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.132</link>            <description> <p>The e-book consortia pilot project was funded by Jisc Collections during 2012/2013 and managed by Information Power Ltd. The aim of the project was to see if there is an effective way to purchase e-books on a title-by-title basis with a collaborative group of academic libraries. The project explored a range of questions including: did all books receive sufficient use to provide value for money for libraries; how such an initiative could be equitably funded by libraries; how much would publishers charge; what benefits there would be for participating publishers; and how it would be managed. The project focused on engineering e-books, and usage data and cost data was collected and analysed in depth.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Hazel Woodward</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Helen Henderson</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.145">        <title>A day in the life of <i>an open scholarship manager</i> </title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.145</link>                <dc:creator>Ina Smith</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.143">        <title>Profile - Stella Butler</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.143</link>                    <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.147">        <title>People</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.147</link>                <dc:creator>John Jardine</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.134">        <title>Roasting the old chestnut: promoting the practitioner perspective to information studies students</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.134</link>            <description> <p>This co-authored article outlines a new initiative from UKSG, working with the Brighton University information studies students and their course leader to devise and pilot a balanced presentation that fits into the curriculum. The article presents the practical challenges of delivering and organizing such an event so that it is a genuinely joint and valuable experience for the students, the academic taking part and UKSG.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Jane Harvell</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Audrey Marshall</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.142">        <title>Key Issue - How to share and discuss your research successfully online</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.142</link>                <dc:creator>Megan Beech</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.133">        <title>Finch 18 months on: a review of progress</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.133</link>            <description>Since the Finch Report was published in 2012, research funders, universities, publishers and learned societies in the UK have all instituted new policies and procedures to accelerate the transition to open access. This paper reports on a review of progress undertaken by the Finch Group, and points to some areas, including monitoring of costs, licensing, but above all co-ordination between the different stakeholder groups, where further action is required.</description>            <dc:creator>Michael Jubb</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-03-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-03-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>28</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>     <item rdf:about="http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.135">        <title>How can existing open access models work for humanities and social science research?</title>    <link>http://insights.uksg.org/article/view/2048-7754.135</link>            <description>This article addresses some of the issues arising from the continuing research and debate on open access (OA) publishing, primarily from the perspective of an academic in the field of humanities.
